comments.body:
the tests got moved to another machine and this started happening.  This problem is likely environmental.  reporting here as
the results are conistently showing the failure in the public reports.

author.name: myrna
author.emailAddress: m dot v dot lunteren at gmail dot com

comments.body:
I've looked at this a bit, because it popped up on a number of branches. As it started failing after I moved the tests on those branches to new machines (with a different OS, and on vmware), and there were no relevant changes in derby code, it seemed indicated that there was something different about those machine.
Also noteworthy was that the tests didn't fail for 10.8 and 10.5 branches, and only failed for weme, not any other jvms. 

The problem is really that this test did not try to find out the correct executable. The master shows the test expects to spawn a process using the executable name 'java'. The executable for weme is 'j9'. The machines where this passed with weme, had an additional jvm installed in the windows system directory, so it was actually spawning that. Presumably this was true on the old machines for the other branches too.
With 10.10 and trunk this has been corrected by converting the test to a junit test, where it figures out the correct executable.

I have the following options for fixing this:
1) add a jvm to the system path on the machines where this was failing
2) disable the test for weme in all derbyall runs on all branches
3) correct the test, i.e. making it look for the j9 executable if that's the jvm we're running with, and either add an additional j9 canon to the master directory and/or add more ignoring code for the _sed.properties file


At this point however, I'm not interested in adding complexity of a proper check for the older branches and either add, and I prefer to just disable this test with weme there.

updateAuthor.name: myrna
updateAuthor.emailAddress: m dot v dot lunteren at gmail dot com

comments.body:
derbyrunjartest now is skipped with weme for all branches from 10.3 to 10.9. (it's running in junit form with 10.10). I do not run weme with 10.2, and there is no derbyrun.jar so no test for it on 10.1, so I'm not backporting that further.

I also disabled the test store/bootLock.java in 10.4 (revision 1491881) and 10.3 (revision 1491882) which was failing for the same reasons, so I referred to this JIRA number even though it's not in the title.
This test too is running fine with weme in junit form, i.e. 10.5 and up.

I will leave this open to confirm the bootLock test is getting skipped, and I may backport that to 10.2 and 10.1.

updateAuthor.name: myrna
updateAuthor.emailAddress: m dot v dot lunteren at gmail dot com

author.name: myrna
author.emailAddress: m dot v dot lunteren at gmail dot com

comments.body:
The bootLock test is now getting skipped with weme/10.3 and 10.4. 
There's no need to backport that any further, so I'm resolving this issue.

author.name: myrna
author.emailAddress: m dot v dot lunteren at gmail dot com

comments.body: I did notice that a similar issue (calling the 'native2ascii' executable, which is not available with a j9.executable, in this case, wctme5.7 (foundation profile)) with 10.1, in the test i18n/JapanCodeConversion. It seems there's always been a jvm available where I was running that test. Marked it under this issue, as it doesn't really deserve its own JIRA.
